I think "interpolation" is a better word for it than "simulation". "AI" is very good at interpolation, not so good at simulation. Take the "filling whiskey glass" for instance. You "cheated" by saying it should fill the glass, so it generates a filling effect. However, a simulation would continue working after the glass fills up, spilling over, getting the table wet and eventually filling the room; that will not happen with the effect in the footage.

The main issue I see is consistency. What a physics system provides is, the developers know the system is working based on a set of rules that are followed. AI art has a tendency to hallucinate or produce inconsistent output, especially applied over a long period of time. Maybe some inconsistency could be visually okay in hard to calculate at scale physics simulations (like fire or water or gas physics) but even lighting on characters might be too much to expect. I do not think it could consistently and believeably light a character in every conceivable environment. I agree with what others have said; AI is not calculating any physics, any more than a great painter calculates lighting effects on clouds. The painter has a wealth of experience with cloudns and knows how they should look under different lighting scenarios - the same with AI.

This is akin to intuitive understanding. Where, you essentially understand something to be the case, without actually understanding why it's the case. no, I'm surprised someone who runs this many simulations would even think that this is physics. the software doesn't need to do physics because it is referencing videos that feature actual physics. if the video it was trained on was all comprised of total chaos it would never be able to generate these images. it is simply compiling countless similar images into one, and it is relying entirely on what it's detecting of the edges in the original video that allows it to find similar imagery. there isn't a shred of simulation happening here.

I doubt AI post processing could ever replace something as big as in-engine physics simulation because of the interactive nature of video games. At the end of the day, what it is is just a filter. I do think that this technology does have a place in video games though, which I think is already being used but many people may not aware. Like in Cyberpunk 2077 they have ray reconstruction for denoising when using ray tracing/path tracing, which is basically a technology that uses AI (machine learning) to enhance things like lighting accuracy, reflection quality, reduce ghosting, etc. And I believe AI in video games should stay as just that, enhancers. Whether it is used to enhance things like visuals with raytracing or to enhance performance with things like DLSS or Frame Generation. The use of AI in that way, for video games, I support

Whenever people talk about AI making it "easier for the little guys", I think of the anime This Boy Suffers from Crystalization. It's a small indie project that was written and animated all by one person. The animation is more like a clip show, the story is confusing, and the art is pretty rough — but I adore it. I've rewatched it many times, thinking about all of the hard work the creator must of put into it. How many hours, weeks, months, years they spent on it. Hi love the content. Here's what I hope for in G.T.A. VI: - Missions not being so linear. I'd like the freedom to be able to complete missions how I want to, like being undiscovered for example. Right now, as of G.T.A. V, we have no options within the most mission parameters but to be discovered, because the mission parameters demand us confront the bad guys. E.g. the mission where we have to chase that actor from the movie studios, right at the beginning, we could have just sniped him from distance instead of being taken on an arduous chase. But, sniping him gives an instant fail. We can only complete missions as Rockstar want us complete them. - Avatar capability. When we run from cops, why can't we climb drain-pipes, clamber across buildings, and jump between them? We just end up ragdolling. - Better weapon control. At times, by the time we've retrieved weapons, and tried to turn aim and shoot. Whoever we're controlling, just has a spaz-attack and fumbles with his weapon as the screen rotates. Annoying as f. - Disguises. Why couldn't we use disguises when we chose to in G.T.A. V? It worked with the janitor disguise when we set fire to that building, and with the biker-cop disguise when we were chasing those two cars for Devon Weston, so why couldn't we dress up in hunting gear and fatigues, and go into Fort Zancudo? Theories: - I think that the Police and the Biker Gang are linked. I can't remember... was it a post card for Ambrosia that said something like 'The Biker Gang take car of everything else' We've seen that Jason has 'forces' history, a Ranger or something. What usually are professions that ex-service men go into? Police, Private Security, BIKER GANGS????? - I think that part of the plot of G.T.A. VI is going to be an investigation. In L.A. Noir we collected evidence as per investigations (C.S.I. sorta thing), in G.T.A. V, as players of the game we conducted investigations via external and in game materials, such as for the Infinite 8 killer. So what's the next step? An in-game investigation that's part of the plot of G.T.A. VI, which the character that we control are investigating? We already know that the police chief (or whoever it was) in Trailer 2 was corrupt. So, it could be an internal investigation into the corruption in the police department. Or, it could be an investigation into the links between the Police Dept. and The Biker Gang. Question: Why are their so many buoys in the harbour? Are they for ship navigation / harbour control? Are they placed specifically for in-game water sports? Do they mark underwater hazards? Do they mark shipwrecks/treasure locations? Do they mark where there are underwater activities? Best wishes with your channel.

key_facts_from_comments: FACT: Co-Pilot requires 1,000 gallons of water to cool down after a single question, raising environmental concerns.
FACT: Microsoft is pushing voice mode to collect user voice data without clear consent.
FACT: AI-generated content in games may lead to inconsistent physics simulations and visual artifacts.
FACT: The pouring water demo shows AI filling glasses independently without tracking total volume changes.
FACT: AI in games could be used for mundane tasks like answering keybinds or settings questions.
FACT: Some users believe AI NPCs could remember player actions and build long-term relationships.
FACT: The AI in the video game simulation appears to learn from player interactions over time.
FACT: The AI in the simulation responds to player input with increasingly complex and self-aware dialogue.
FACT: AI-generated game content may not simulate real-world physics but instead interpolates based on training data.
FACT: AI is being used in post-processing for denoising and enhancing lighting in games like Cyberpunk 2077.
FACT: The AI in the simulation can generate dynamic NPC responses based on player behavior and questions.
FACT: Some users fear AI will replace human creativity in game development and reduce artistic value.
FACT: AI-generated game art often lacks emotional depth and feels 'nauseating' or 'sad' compared to hand-crafted work.
FACT: AI-generated game covers are already appearing on platforms like the E-shop, often poorly designed.
FACT: AI can be trained to mimic specific character voices, such as James Earl Jones, raising ethical concerns.
key_opinions_from_comments: OPINION: AI in gaming is a forced marketing gimmick that undermines genuine creativity and player agency.
OPINION: AI-generated NPCs should only assist with basic gameplay help, not replace narrative depth.
OPINION: The idea of AI learning from players and reacting emotionally is both exciting and deeply unsettling.
OPINION: AI in games will make them more interactive, but only if it respects player autonomy and privacy.
OPINION: AI should not be used to generate entire games or replace human developers entirely.
OPINION: AI-generated content is a symptom of a broader industry crisis driven by profit over quality.
OPINION: The environmental cost of running AI models makes their use in consumer products unjustifiable.
OPINION: AI NPCs that feel too real could blur the line between game and reality, leading to psychological distress.
OPINION: AI should not be used to generate content that mimics real people’s voices or likenesses without consent.
OPINION: The future of gaming should prioritize human creativity, not automated content generation.
OPINION: AI in games risks turning players into passive consumers rather than active participants.
OPINION: AI-generated game content is inherently exploitative, especially when used to flood marketplaces with low-quality products.
OPINION: The current hype around AI in gaming is driven by investors, not actual consumer demand.
OPINION: AI should enhance tools for artists and developers, not replace them.
OPINION: AI in games could lead to a new wave of digital addiction and escapism, especially with UBI.
